conclusion: Determine the ratio of the length of the light-emitting part on the edge to the length of the edge using properties of triangles and the law of sines.
The top angle of the cross section is 30 degrees.
Since angle OSN = 30 degrees and the refraction angle is 45 degrees, find angle OSA and angle SNA.
Angle SNA = 180 degrees - angle OSN - angle AOS = 180 degrees - 30 degrees - angle AOS.
In triangle OSN, the law of sines states: OS/sin(angle SNA) = SN/sin(angle OSN).
Find angle SNA and angle OSN. Since angle OSN = 30 degrees and angle OSA = 135 degrees, then angle AOS = 180 degrees - 135 degrees = 45 degrees.
Therefore, angle SNA = 180 degrees - 30 degrees - 45 degrees = 105 degrees.
The ratio of the lengths of the sides is given by the ratio of the sines of the opposite angles.
In triangle OSN, the ratio of the lengths of the sides is: OS/SN = sin(105 degrees)/sin(30 degrees).
sin(105 degrees) = sin(180 degrees - 75 degrees) = sin(75 degrees) = sin(45 degrees + 30 degrees) = sin(45 degrees)cos(30 degrees) + cos(45 degrees)sin(30 degrees).
The ratio of the length of the light-emitting part to the length of the edge is the same as the ratio of the lengths of the sides in the triangle.
